One of them hits a downspout, knocking it onto the lawn. SOUNDS as these pieces of granite tear into the stucco ro The effect is that of a drum being bombarded.

dialogues.text: As one final stone В­ this one the size of a mere pebble the lawn. The image grows lighter and lighter. All the color seems once again into an incredible, silently blazing white. MAIN TITLES.

dialogues.text: Now some years later В­ and no longer glistening so white front of the house as the door flies open. Carrie, now si doorway, carrying school books. As she comes out on the p behind her. She is wearing a shapeless, drab dress В­ much too long, without style. What remains in this adolescent girl that glimpsed in the prologue are those remarkable eyes. As she comes down the porch stairs, we hear:

They banter little barbed pleasantries, bits of talk of college В­ all of which we hear from separate sta One by one the showers are turned off, the girls stepping toweling, spraying deodorant, bras hooked, underpants ste So do words, running into one another, tumbling, drifting `...Tommy says he hated it on me... My sister's husband p sister... too cheap to spend a penny... we'll go after sc meet you... Friday night...' We PICK UP Miss Collins as she steps among the girls, spi shower. In a virtual moving her hands over her breasts in small, regular, virt out of frame, below her stomach. Slowly, it emerges back just as she and we see this, so do the girls. CHRIS

dialogues.text: HENRY MORTON, the principal, a decent but somewhat ploddi tapping out his pipe as he talks to Collins. MORTON Isn't she a bit old for her...

dialogues.text: Miss Collins, if you'd been with us longer, you'd understand we cannot interfere with people's beliefs. As for the girls В­ COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ummm. COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to go to the infirmary?... Carrie is shaking her head. MORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...lie down for a while... COLLINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Carrie can go home. MORTON Would you like a ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, Carrie is shaking her head. MORTON We could call you a cab. COLLINS I'm sure she can walk home. And Carrie, you're excused from gym for a week. Take study hall instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morton picks up the dismissal slip, hands it to Carrie. MORTON We are sorry about this, Cassie. CARRIE (sudden fury) That's not my name!

dialogues.text: Two things happen simultaneously; Morton recoils slightly and then tumbles from the desk. Then Carrie goes out. Morton comes around the desk, stoops to pick up the ashtr moment, then looks at Collins. COLLINS (slowly) That reminds me. A light blew out while I was trying to calm her down. MORTON I'll send a janitor to fix it.

dialogues.text: Okay, that's reality. He puts the ashtray back on the des "peculiar" thought he may have had.
